questions.definition: The ability of an object to move through the air and remain airborne.
An upward force that counteracts the weight of an object, allowing it to rise.
A force that resists an object's motion through air, acting opposite to the direction of movement.
The force that propels an object forward through the air.
The force that pulls objects toward the Earth, opposing lift in flight.
The study of how air moves around objects, such as airplanes or birds.
A specially designed shape of a wing or blade that creates lift by affecting air pressure.
The side-to-side movement of an object around its vertical axis, used to change direction in flight.
The up or down tilting motion of an object around its horizontal axis.
The rotation of an object around its longitudinal axis, tilting it side to side.
The ability of an object in flight to maintain balance and resist unwanted movements.
A surface designed to generate lift and enable flight.
The main body of an aircraft, housing passengers, cargo, and controls.
A rotating blade that generates thrust to move an aircraft forward.
A type of engine that uses high-speed exhaust gases to produce thrust.
The height of an object above the Earth's surface.
Irregular or chaotic motion in the air that affects smooth flight.
A small vertical extension at the tips of a wing to reduce drag and improve efficiency.
The point where an object's weight is evenly distributed, crucial for stability in flight.
A scientific concept explaining how faster-moving air creates lower pressure, aiding in lift generation.
A hinged surface on a wing used to control roll and direction during flight.
A control surface on the tail of an aircraft that adjusts pitch.
A vertical control surface on the tail that helps control yaw.
A measure of an object's aerodynamic efficiency, comparing lift generated to drag experienced.
An aircraft that flies without an engine, relying on air currents and lift.
